trans-unit.source: Build and deploy a Node.js API app in Azure App Service | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Build and deploy a Node.js API app in Azure App Service | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create a Node.js API app package and deploy it to Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create a Node.js API app package and deploy it to Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: Build and deploy a Node.js API app in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Build and deploy a Node.js API app in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to create a <link><linkText>Node.js</linkText><title></title></link> application and deploy it to Azure App Service API Apps using <link><linkText>Git</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to create a <link><linkText>Node.js</linkText><title></title></link> application and deploy it to Azure App Service API Apps using <link><linkText>Git</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The instructions in this tutorial can be followed on any operating system that is capable of running Node.
trans-unit.target: The instructions in this tutorial can be followed on any operating system that is capable of running Node.

trans-unit.source: The screenshot below shows you the completed application:
trans-unit.target: The screenshot below shows you the completed application:

trans-unit.source: You can also use Visual Studio Code to build an deploy a Node.js API app in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: You can also use Visual Studio Code to build an deploy a Node.js API app in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Visual Studio Code and Node.js, see <link><linkText>Visual Studio Code</linkText><title></title></link> and <link><linkText>Developing Node Applications</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Visual Studio Code and Node.js, see <link><linkText>Visual Studio Code</linkText><title></title></link> and <link><linkText>Developing Node Applications</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Create an API app in the Azure preview Portal
trans-unit.target: Create an API app in the Azure preview Portal

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you need a Microsoft Azure account.
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you need a Microsoft Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can <link><linkText>activate your MSDN subscriber benefits</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>sign up for a free trial</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can <link><linkText>activate your MSDN subscriber benefits</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>sign up for a free trial</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You can also try for free <link><linkText>App Service App Samples</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can also try for free <link><linkText>App Service App Samples</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Log in to the <link><linkText>Azure preview portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Log in to the <link><linkText>Azure preview portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Click NEW at the bottom left of the portal.
trans-unit.target: Click NEW at the bottom left of the portal.

trans-unit.source: Click Web + Mobile > API App.
trans-unit.target: Click Web + Mobile > API App.

trans-unit.source: Enter a value for Name, such as NodejsAPIApp.
trans-unit.target: Enter a value for Name, such as NodejsAPIApp.

trans-unit.source: Select an App Service plan or create a new one.
trans-unit.target: Select an App Service plan or create a new one.

trans-unit.source: If you create a new plan, select the pricing tier, location, and other options.
trans-unit.target: If you create a new plan, select the pricing tier, location, and other options.

trans-unit.source: Click Create.
trans-unit.target: Click Create.

trans-unit.source: If you left Add to Startboard check box selected, the portal automatically opens the blade for your API app after it's created.
trans-unit.target: If you left Add to Startboard check box selected, the portal automatically opens the blade for your API app after it's created.

trans-unit.source: If you cleared the checkbox, click Notifications on the portal home page to see the API app creation status, and click the notification to go to the blade for the new API app.
trans-unit.target: If you cleared the checkbox, click Notifications on the portal home page to see the API app creation status, and click the notification to go to the blade for the new API app.

trans-unit.source: Click Settings > Application Settings.
trans-unit.target: Click Settings > Application Settings.

trans-unit.source: Set the Access level to Public (anonymous).
trans-unit.target: Set the Access level to Public (anonymous).

trans-unit.source: Click Save.
trans-unit.target: Click Save.

trans-unit.source: Enable Git publishing for the new API app
trans-unit.target: Enable Git publishing for the new API app

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Git</linkText><title></title></link> is a distributed version control system that you can use to deploy your Azure Website.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Git</linkText><title></title></link> is a distributed version control system that you can use to deploy your Azure Website.

trans-unit.source: You'll store the code you write for your API app in a local Git repository, and you'll deploy your code to Azure by pushing to a remote repository.
trans-unit.target: You'll store the code you write for your API app in a local Git repository, and you'll deploy your code to Azure by pushing to a remote repository.

trans-unit.source: This method of deployment is a feature of App Service web apps that you can use in an API app because API apps are based on web apps: an API app in Azure App Service is a web app with additional features for hosting web services.
trans-unit.target: This method of deployment is a feature of App Service web apps that you can use in an API app because API apps are based on web apps: an API app in Azure App Service is a web app with additional features for hosting web services.

trans-unit.source: In the portal you manage the features specific to API apps in the API App blade, and you manage the features that are shared with web apps in the API App Host blade.
trans-unit.target: In the portal you manage the features specific to API apps in the API App blade, and you manage the features that are shared with web apps in the API App Host blade.

trans-unit.source: So in this section you go to the API App Host blade to configure the Git deployment feature.
trans-unit.target: So in this section you go to the API App Host blade to configure the Git deployment feature.

trans-unit.source: In the API App blade, click API App host.
trans-unit.target: In the API App blade, click API App host.

trans-unit.source: Find the Deployment section of the API App blade and click Set up continuous deployment.
trans-unit.target: Find the Deployment section of the API App blade and click Set up continuous deployment.

trans-unit.source: You may need to scroll down to see this part of the blade.
trans-unit.target: You may need to scroll down to see this part of the blade.

trans-unit.source: Click Choose Source > Local Git Repository.
trans-unit.target: Click Choose Source > Local Git Repository.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: If you have not previously set up deployment credentials for publishing an API app or other App Service app, set them up now:
trans-unit.target: If you have not previously set up deployment credentials for publishing an API app or other App Service app, set them up now:

trans-unit.source: Click Set deployment credentials.
trans-unit.target: Click Set deployment credentials.

trans-unit.source: Create a user name and password.
trans-unit.target: Create a user name and password.

trans-unit.source: Click Save.
trans-unit.target: Click Save.

trans-unit.source: In the API App Host blade, click Settings > Properties.
trans-unit.target: In the API App Host blade, click Settings > Properties.

trans-unit.source: The URL of the remote Git repository that you'll deploy to is shown under "GIT URL".
trans-unit.target: The URL of the remote Git repository that you'll deploy to is shown under "GIT URL".

trans-unit.source: Copy the URL for use later in the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Copy the URL for use later in the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Download and inspect code for a Node.js API app
trans-unit.target: Download and inspect code for a Node.js API app

trans-unit.source: In this section, you'll download and take a look at the code provided as part of the NodeAPIApp sample.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you'll download and take a look at the code provided as part of the NodeAPIApp sample.

trans-unit.source: Download the code in this GitHub repository. You can either clone the repository or click Download Zip to download it as a .zip file. If you download the .zip file, unzip it in your local disk.
trans-unit.target: Download the code in this GitHub repository. You can either clone the repository or click Download Zip to download it as a .zip file. If you download the .zip file, unzip it in your local disk.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the folder were you unzipped the sample.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the folder were you unzipped the sample.

trans-unit.source: Open the apiapp.json file in a text editor and inspect the contents.
trans-unit.target: Open the apiapp.json file in a text editor and inspect the contents.

trans-unit.source: Azure App Service has two prerequisites in order to recognize a Node.js application as an API App:
trans-unit.target: Azure App Service has two prerequisites in order to recognize a Node.js application as an API App:

trans-unit.source: A file named apiapp.json has to be present in the root directory of the application.
trans-unit.target: A file named apiapp.json has to be present in the root directory of the application.

trans-unit.source: A Swagger 2.0 metadata endpoint has to be exposed by the application.
trans-unit.target: A Swagger 2.0 metadata endpoint has to be exposed by the application.

trans-unit.source: The URL of this endpoint is specified in the apiapp.json file.
trans-unit.target: The URL of this endpoint is specified in the apiapp.json file.

trans-unit.source: Notice the apiDefinition property.
trans-unit.target: Notice the apiDefinition property.

trans-unit.source: The path for this URL is relative to your API's URL and it points to the Swagger 2.0 endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The path for this URL is relative to your API's URL and it points to the Swagger 2.0 endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Azure App Service uses this property to discover the definition of your API and enable many of the App Service API app capabilities.
trans-unit.target: Azure App Service uses this property to discover the definition of your API and enable many of the App Service API app capabilities.

trans-unit.source: The endpoint has to be of Swagger 2.0 specification, as older versions (e.g. 1.2) are not supported by the platform.
trans-unit.target: The endpoint has to be of Swagger 2.0 specification, as older versions (e.g. 1.2) are not supported by the platform.

trans-unit.source: The sample application is using swaggerize-express to create a Swagger 2.0 specification endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The sample application is using swaggerize-express to create a Swagger 2.0 specification endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Open the server.js file and inspect the code.
trans-unit.target: Open the server.js file and inspect the code.

trans-unit.source: The code uses the swaggerize-express module to create the Swagger 2.0 endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The code uses the swaggerize-express module to create the Swagger 2.0 endpoint.

trans-unit.source: The api property points to the api.json file which contains the Swagger 2.0 spec definition of our API.
trans-unit.target: The api property points to the api.json file which contains the Swagger 2.0 spec definition of our API.

trans-unit.source: You can manually create the file in a text editor or use the online <link><linkText>editor of Swagger</linkText><title></title></link> and download the JSON file from there.
trans-unit.target: You can manually create the file in a text editor or use the online <link><linkText>editor of Swagger</linkText><title></title></link> and download the JSON file from there.

trans-unit.source: (The api.json file specifies a host property but the value of this property is determined and replaced dynamically at runtime.)
trans-unit.target: (The api.json file specifies a host property but the value of this property is determined and replaced dynamically at runtime.)

trans-unit.source: The docspath property points to the Swagger 2.0 endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The docspath property points to the Swagger 2.0 endpoint.

trans-unit.source: This URL is relative to the base path of your API.
trans-unit.target: This URL is relative to the base path of your API.

trans-unit.source: The base path is declared in the api.json file.
trans-unit.target: The base path is declared in the api.json file.

trans-unit.source: In our example the base path is /api/data, so the relative path to the swagger endpoint is /api/data/swagger.
trans-unit.target: In our example the base path is /api/data, so the relative path to the swagger endpoint is /api/data/swagger.

trans-unit.source: As the base path is declared in the api.json file, trying to access the /swagger endpoint as a relative path to your API app's URL will return 404.
trans-unit.target: As the base path is declared in the api.json file, trying to access the /swagger endpoint as a relative path to your API app's URL will return 404.

trans-unit.source: This is a common mistake when trying to access the swagger endpoint.
trans-unit.target: This is a common mistake when trying to access the swagger endpoint.

trans-unit.source: The handlers property points to the local folder that contains the route handlers for the Express.js module.
trans-unit.target: The handlers property points to the local folder that contains the route handlers for the Express.js module.

trans-unit.source: Run the API app code locally
trans-unit.target: Run the API app code locally

trans-unit.source: In this section you run the application locally to verify it works prior to deployment.
trans-unit.target: In this section you run the application locally to verify it works prior to deployment.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the folder were you downloaded the sample.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the folder were you downloaded the sample.

trans-unit.source: Open a command line prompt and enter the following command:
trans-unit.target: Open a command line prompt and enter the following command:

trans-unit.source: When the install command finishes, enter the following command:
trans-unit.target: When the install command finishes, enter the following command:

trans-unit.source: The command line window output shows "Server started .."
trans-unit.target: The command line window output shows "Server started .."

trans-unit.source: Navigate your browser to http://localhost:1337/
trans-unit.target: Navigate your browser to http://localhost:1337/

trans-unit.source: You see the following page
trans-unit.target: You see the following page

trans-unit.source: To view the Swagger.json file, navigate to http://localhost:1337/api/data/swagger.
trans-unit.target: To view the Swagger.json file, navigate to http://localhost:1337/api/data/swagger.

trans-unit.source: Publish your API app code to Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Publish your API app code to Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: In this section you create a local Git repository and push from that repository to Azure in order to deploy your sample application to the API app running in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: In this section you create a local Git repository and push from that repository to Azure in order to deploy your sample application to the API app running in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: If Git is not installed, install it from <link><linkText>the Git download page</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If Git is not installed, install it from <link><linkText>the Git download page</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: From the command-line, change directories to the sample application directory and enter the following commands to initialize a local Git repository.
trans-unit.target: From the command-line, change directories to the sample application directory and enter the following commands to initialize a local Git repository.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following commands to add files to the repository:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following commands to add files to the repository:

trans-unit.source: Create a remote reference for pushing updates to the web app (API app host) you created previously, using the Git URL that you copied earlier:
trans-unit.target: Create a remote reference for pushing updates to the web app (API app host) you created previously, using the Git URL that you copied earlier:

trans-unit.source: Push your changes to Azure by entering the following command:
trans-unit.target: Push your changes to Azure by entering the following command:

trans-unit.source: You are prompted for the password you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: You are prompted for the password you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: The output from this command ends with a message that deployment is successful:
trans-unit.target: The output from this command ends with a message that deployment is successful:

trans-unit.source: View the API definition in the Azure preview portal
trans-unit.target: View the API definition in the Azure preview portal

trans-unit.source: Now that you've deployed an API to your API app, you can see the API definition in the Azure preview portal.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've deployed an API to your API app, you can see the API definition in the Azure preview portal.

trans-unit.source: You'll begin by restarting the gateway, which enables Azure to recognize that an API app's API definition has changed.
trans-unit.target: You'll begin by restarting the gateway, which enables Azure to recognize that an API app's API definition has changed.

trans-unit.source: The gateway is a web app that handles API administration and authorization for the API apps in a resource group.
trans-unit.target: The gateway is a web app that handles API administration and authorization for the API apps in a resource group.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure preview portal, go to the API App blade for the API app that you created earlier, and click the Gateway link.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure preview portal, go to the API App blade for the API app that you created earlier, and click the Gateway link.

trans-unit.source: In the Gateway blade, click Restart.
trans-unit.target: In the Gateway blade, click Restart.

trans-unit.source: You can now close this blade.
trans-unit.target: You can now close this blade.

trans-unit.source: In the API App blade, click API Definition.
trans-unit.target: In the API App blade, click API Definition.

trans-unit.source: The API Definition blade shows two Get methods.
trans-unit.target: The API Definition blade shows two Get methods.

trans-unit.source: Run the sample application in Azure
trans-unit.target: Run the sample application in Azure

trans-unit.source: In the Azure preview portal, go to the API App Host blade for your API app, and click Browse .
trans-unit.target: In the Azure preview portal, go to the API App Host blade for your API app, and click Browse .

trans-unit.source: The browser displays the home page that you saw earlier when you ran the sample app locally.
trans-unit.target: The browser displays the home page that you saw earlier when you ran the sample app locally.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: You've deployed a Node.js web application that uses an API app backend to Azure.
trans-unit.target: You've deployed a Node.js web application that uses an API app backend to Azure.

trans-unit.source: For more information about using Node.js in Azure, see the <link><linkText>Node.js Developer Center</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about using Node.js in Azure, see the <link><linkText>Node.js Developer Center</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You can try this sample API App at <link><linkText>TryApp Service</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: You can try this sample API App at <link><linkText>TryApp Service</linkText><title></title></link>
